conversation.content:
Assignment 3
In this assignment we will be practicing conditional rendering and lifting state up!

Step 0 - Setup​
Create a Next.js using our starter code with the following command:

yarn create next-app --typescript --example "https://github.com/cornell-dti/trends-sp23-a3" YOUR_PROJECT_NAME
if that command doesn't work, try

npx create-next-app --typescript --example "https://github.com/cornell-dti/trends-sp23-a3" YOUR_PROJECT_NAME
Step 1 - Hit The Ground Running​
As with A2, run yarn dev in the project directory to start the server and navigate to localhost:3000 to see what the starter code gives you.

Here are the important files you'll be working with:

React Components
components/game/Game.tsx
This is where our game state will live and be passed down from!
Splits the UI into two sections, each of which is its own React component
components/game/ClickerSection.tsx
Displays the number of BRBs you have, as well as other stats
Has a button that should give you BRBs when clicked
components/game/UpgradesSection.tsx
Displays a list of upgrades using the UpgradeDisplay component
Fairly simple - is just a wrapper around the upgrade list
components/game/UpgradeDisplay.tsx
Displays stats of a particular upgrade (purchased count, price, etc)
Has a button that should buy the upgrade when clicked
Other Files
data/index.ts
Where all your GAME DATA ?? is
Make sure to add at least one more upgrade to your game
types/index.ts
Just has one type: Upgrade
No need to change in this assignment
As always, make sure to fill in all the TODOs before submitting!

Step 2 - Dealing with Lifted State​
In A2, we had the whole game all in one component. But now it's in pieces ??

Here is a UML diagram that captures how the starter code is set up:

component diagram

Game.tsx has all the lifted state, but it needs to be passed down! The starter code is not complete, which means that your first task is to pass down the props that the other components need.

Here are all the additional props that need to be passed down:

ClickerSection
brbs
setBRBs
UpgradesSection
setBRBs
upgradeCounts
setUpgradeCounts
UpgradeDisplay
setBRBs
upgradeCounts
setUpgradeCounts
Remember that adding a required prop is a TWO-FOLD process:

In the (child) "receiving component", add it to the Props type
In all (parent) "giving components", supply the prop in JSX (<Component />)
FAQ for Step 2​
What is the type of "setter" functions like setBRBs and setUpgradeCounts?​
Best way to check a type is by hovering over the variable in your IDE!

If you hover over setBRBs, you will see Dispatch<SetStateAction<number>>

You will find that the type for the setter function for useState<T> will be Dispatch<SetStateAction<T>> for some type T representing the state.

Should I always be passing down the state variable/setter function directly to child components?​
You don't have to! We do it in most cases in this assignment for simplicity.

However, you can see that clickIncome and tickIncome is passed down to ClickerSection as props. Since those two values are just a function of upgradeCounts (covered in Step 3), you can pass down upgradeCounts as a prop instead, and do all the calculation in ClickerSection instead of Game.

However(ever), in our assignment we calculate tickIncome in Game instead of ClickerSection because the tick logic is in Game and relies on the value of tickIncome.

TL;DR - Props do not have to mirror state in parent components, you should aim to design them in most understandable/practical way!

Why do the Props types have the readonly thing?​
We like to add the readonly keyword to attributes in Props types to remind ourselves that props are passed down and cannot be directly modified. If we try to do so, we will be warned by TypeScript b/c we have specified it to be readonly. This is an optional code style thing but we like it :)
can i have the full Game.tsx code

Step 3 - Tracking Upgrades​
In A2, we had only 1 upgrade you could buy. Now we can add as many upgrades as we want! However, how do we keep track of how many upgrades we've purchased?

If we have one upgrade, we can keep track of this using a single number. But what if we have n number of upgrades? There are many ways to solve this, such as with an array. However, we will be instead using the following for A3:

The Map class in JavaScript/TypeScript represents a mapping between a unique key and a value. See the MDN docs for more information on Map if you are unfamiliar.

In Game.tsx, we have a state variable called upgradeCounts of type Map<Upgrade, number>. This means that the key is of type Upgrade and the value is of number.

If we have an Upgrade in mind, we can check the corresponding mapped number, which represents how many times that particular upgrade has been purchased.

Accessing upgradeCounts​
We need the values inside upgradeCounts for several parts of the game.

In Game, several stats rely on upgradeCounts.

clickIncome is 1 + the total times purchased across all upgrade categories. Buying any upgrade should increase clickIncome by 1.

tickIncome is the sum of your effective income for each upgrade (incomePerTick * number of times it was purchased)

In UpgradesDisplay, we want to display the number of times the upgrade has been purchased (purchasedCount)

We will also use this purchasedCount value to implement a feature in Step 4!

Hints For Accessing upgradeCounts​
We can use upgradeCounts.get(upgrade) to retrieve the associated value for a given upgrade.

We can use [...upgradeCounts.values()] to get a list of values in the Map.

We can use [...upgradeCounts.entries()] to get a list of [key, value] pairs in the Map.

See MDN docs for more things you can do!

Modifying upgradeCounts​
When we buy an upgrade, we want to increment the associated number in upgradeCounts by 1.

This should happen in the buyUpgrade function in UpgradeDisplay.

Hints For Modifying upgradeCounts​
Remember that you can do either setUpgradeCounts(newValue) or setUpgradeCounts((oldValue) => newValue) to update your state.

To make a change to an existing Map, do the following

// This *modifies* the Map that upgradeCounts points to
// newValue points to the SAME Map as upgradeCounts
const newValue = upgradeCounts.set(key, newValue);
IMPORTANT Note that setUpgradeCounts may not behave as you expect when working with object references. If you call setUpgradeCounts(newValue) where newValue is the same reference as upgradeCounts, then this WILL NOT trigger an update/rerender!

To get around this issue, do the following

const newValue: Map<Upgrade, number> = upgradeCounts;
setUpgradeCounts(newValue); // this is BAD
// Creates a copy of the map so that React knows that newValue is different
setUpgradeCounts(new Map(newValue)); // this is GOOD

Step 4 - Finishing Touches​ We're done with the biggest part of the assignment, which is dealing with upgrades! Now let's add some smaller stuff to make the game cooler :) Here is a list of features to add: In Game, we normally show

BRB Clicker

as the page header. If we've purchased at least one of every upgrade, then do the following: Replace the text with ??BRB Clicker?? instead (with h1 tags still) Right under the header h1 tag, add a win message in a p tag Refresh your memory on Conditional Rendering from Lecture 5 if you're stuck! In ClickerSection, make the "Acquire BRB" button work! Each click should increase BRBs by the value of clickIncome This will be very similar to what you did in A2, using the onClick prop In UpgradeDisplay, we need to increase the price of an upgrade each time we purchase it. In Cookie Clicker, the price increases by 15% every purchase. Let's yoink that! (Make sure to round up to the nearest integer) In UpgradeDisplay, we want to disable the Buy button (make it greyed out and unclickable) if we don't have brbs to afford the next upgrade.

allFacetValues.value: write a Python script that captures a mouse click from the user to get screen coordinates and then performs 50 clicks with a random 1 to 3 second gap between each click.
English
write a Python script to record mouse clicks and automatically perform 50 additional clicks with random intervals between them.

conversation.content: pls write me some python code that firsrt takes a mouse click from the user to get screen co-ords and then performs 50 clicks with a random 1 to 3 second gap between clicks

In this code snippet, I will use the `pyautogui` library to handle mouse clicking and the `random` library to generate random intervals between the clicks.

First, you will need to install the `pyautogui` library if you haven't already. You can do this by running the following command in your terminal:

```shell
pip install pyautogui
```

Here's the code snippet:

```python
import pyautogui
import random
import time

def main():
    print("Please click somewhere on the screen...")
    x, y = pyautogui.position()  # Get the current position of the mouse

    for i in range(50):
        interval = random.randint(1, 3)  # Generate a random interval between 1 and 3 seconds
        time.sleep(interval)  # Wait for the interval
        pyautogui.click(x, y)  # Click at the (x, y) position

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

This script will ask the user to click somewhere, then it will capture the click's screen coordinates and perform 50 clicks with a random 1 to 3-second gap between clicks. Note that this script won't actually wait for the user to click before starting; it will capture the current position of the mouse when it starts running. A better approach would be to use a GUI library (such as PyQt or Tkinter) to actually wait for the user to click on the screen, but this solution should work for a basic implementation.

conversation.content: How should I get the player controller inside ActivateAbility in an ability?
Is it okay to get the player controller in ability or is there a better way to do this?

Getting the player controller directly in the ability can work, but it's generally considered a better practice to not rely on the player controller within an ability, as abilities should be designed to work independently of specific player input. Instead of getting the player controller directly in the ability, you should try to design your abilities and game mechanics around input-independent systems and parameters.

For example, if your ability needs information from the player controller, consider passing this information to the ability when activating it, using AttributeSet or gameplay events:

1. Create a custom AttributeSet class and define the variables that you want to pass from the player controller to the ability. Then, create a gameplay event for the ability activation with these variables as payload.

2. In your player controller, handle input events and gather the required information. Setup the payload for your gameplay event and trigger the event when the ability is activated.

3. In your ability, override the function HandleGameplayEvent to catch the event with the payload. From there, you can extract the required information and execute your ability logic accordingly.

This approach allows your abilities to remain more modular and independent of player input, improving overall code design and flexibility.
How can I create the targeting actor in the player controller but also access the targeting actor in the ability. Should I pass it through the payload?
How do I use TSharedPtr inside an ability class in ue5 gas?

I am trying to create my targeting widget inside my player controller like so 	TargetActorGroundTrace = GetWorld()->SpawnActor<ARagnaAbilTargetActor_GroundTrace>(TargetActorGroundTraceClass);
	return TargetActorGroundTrace; I am return a pointer to my targeting widget so I can keep a reference to the widget inside my controller class. Then I pass the targeting widget into my ability using a payload. I want the ability to destroy my widget once the ability is activated and used. Is this okay or is there another, better, faster way to do this?
Is this the best absolute way of doing things?

The method described above for handling the targeting widget creation/destruction in the player controller and passing its reference to the ability using a payload is generally a good and efficient way to do it. It adheres to best practices in maintaining the independence of abilities from specific player input mechanisms while making sure UObject-derived classes are managed correctly.

However, it may not be the "best absolute way" in all scenarios, as various aspects of game design may necessitate different approaches. Always consider how the design and architecture of your game fit into the GAS (Gameplay Ability System) framework and use methods that suit your specific needs and constraints.

That being said, the method explained above is suitable for most common scenarios, and you can implement this in your project with confidence that it will provide a maintainable, flexible, and efficient way to manage your targeting widgets and abilities.

conversation.content: with pyautogui, how can I send a press key event to another window?

To send a press key event to another window using PyAutoGUI, you can follow these steps:

1. Get the window's handle using the `win32gui` module. You can use `win32gui.FindWindow()` or `win32gui.FindWindowEx()` function to get the handle.

2. Activate the window using the `win32gui.SetForegroundWindow()` function. This will bring the window to the front and give it focus.

3. Use the `pyautogui.press()` function to send the key press event to the active window.

Here's an example code:

```python
import pyautogui
import win32gui

# Find the window handle
window_title = "My Window Title"
hwnd = win32gui.FindWindow(None, window_title)

if hwnd != 0:
    # Activate the window
    win32gui.SetForegroundWindow(hwnd)

    # Send a key press event
    pyautogui.press('a')
```

Replace `window_title` with the title of the window you want to send key press events to. You can also use `win32gui.GetClassName()` or `win32gui.GetWindowText()` functions to get the window handle based on its class name or text.
pyautogui.press("s") isn't sending the letter to the window, it does change focus but that is all it does

If `pyautogui.press("s")` is changing the focus to the window but not actually typing the letter "s" in the window, it's possible that the window you're trying to send the key press event to is not in focus or the keyboard input is being blocked by another application or security settings.

You can try using the `pyautogui.typewrite()` function instead of `pyautogui.press()` to send the keystroke. `typewrite()` simulates the keyboard keypresses as if you were typing them from the keyboard.

```python
import pyautogui
import time

# Wait for window to be in foreground
time.sleep(2)

# Type 's' keystroke 
pyautogui.typewrite('s')
```

Make sure the window you want to send the keystroke to is in focus before running the script. You can also use the `pyautogui.click()` or `pyautogui.moveTo()` functions to set the focus to the window before sending the keystroke.
still doesn't send the keystroke even with focus on the window

If the `pyautogui.typewrite()` function is not sending the keystroke even with focus on the window, it's possible that the application in the window is blocking the input. Some applications have security settings that prevent automated scripts from typing in input fields.

Try using the `pyautogui.write()` function instead of `pyautogui.typewrite()`. The `pyautogui.write()` function sends a string of keystrokes to the active window.

```python
import pyautogui
import time

# Wait for window to be in foreground
time.sleep(2)

# Type 's' keystroke using write() function
pyautogui.write('s')
```

If `pyautogui.write()` still doesn't work, you can try using the `win32api` and `win32con` modules from the `pywin32` package to send the keystrokes. Here is an example code:

```python
import win32api
import win32con

# Wait for window to be in foreground
time.sleep(2)

# Set active window
hwnd = win32gui.FindWindow(None, "Window Title")
win32gui.SetForegroundWindow(hwnd)

# Send 's' keystroke
win32api.keybd_event(ord('s'), 0, 0, 0)
win32api.keybd_event(ord('s'), 0, win32con.KEYEVENTF_KEYUP, 0)
```

Replace `"Window Title"` with the title of the window you want to send the keystroke to. Also, make sure you have installed the `pywin32` package.
both methods didn't worked, any other alternative?

If the previous methods didn't work, another alternative would be to use the Windows API function `SendMessage()` to simulate key presses. You can use the `ctypes` module to call this function from Python.

Here is an example code that sends the 's' key to a window using `SendMessage()`:

```python
import ctypes

# Define constants
WM_KEYDOWN = 0x0100
WM_KEYUP = 0x0101
VK_S = 0x53 # virtual key code for 's'
LPARAM_KEYDOWN = 0x00000001
LPARAM_KEYUP = 0xC0000001

# Get the handle of the window to send the key press to
hwnd = ctypes.windll.user32.FindWindowW(None, "Window Title")

# Set the window to the foreground
ctypes.windll.user32.SetForegroundWindow(hwnd)

# Simulate pressing the 's' key
ctypes.windll.user32.PostMessageW(hwnd, WM_KEYDOWN, VK_S, LPARAM_KEYDOWN)
ctypes.windll.user32.PostMessageW(hwnd, WM_KEYUP, VK_S, LPARAM_KEYUP)
```

Replace `"Window Title"` with the title of the window you want to send the keystroke to.

Note that depending on the application, it may not work to send keystrokes directly to a window. Some applications have security settings or other measures in place to prevent this type of automated input.
didn't work, another alternative?

Another alternative to sending keystrokes to another window is to use the Windows Input Simulator library to simulate keyboard and mouse input. This library allows you to simulate keystrokes and mouse events on both the local and remote machines.

You can install the `inputs` module using `pip`:

```python
!pip install inputs
```

Here is an example code that sends the 's' key to a window using `inputs`:

```python
from inputs import *
import time

# get the window's handle
hwnd = win32gui.FindWindow(None, "Window Title")

# set the window to the foreground
win32gui.SetForegroundWindow(hwnd)

# simulate pressing the 's' key
inputs.send(Keycode.from_vk(0x1f), Keycode.from_vk(0x1f))

time.sleep(0.05)

# simulate releasing the 's' key
inputs.send(Keycode.from_vk(0x1f))
```

Replace `"Window Title"` with the title of the window you want to send the keystroke to.

Note that depending on the application, it may not work to send keystrokes directly to a window. Some applications have security settings or other measures in place to prevent this type of automated input.

NameError: name 'inputs' is not defined

If you are getting a `NameError: name 'inputs' is not defined` error after importing the `inputs` module, it's possible that the module was not installed correctly or there is an issue with your Python environment.

First, make sure that you have installed the `inputs` module correctly by running `pip install inputs` in your command prompt or terminal. You can also try reinstalling the module using `pip install --upgrade inputs`.

If you have installed the module correctly and you still get the `NameError`, try importing the module using the following line of code:

```python
from inputs import devices, Keycode, EventInjector
```

This should import all the necessary classes and functions from the `inputs` module.

Then, you can use the `EventInjector` class to simulate keyboard and mouse events. For example:

```python
import win32gui
from inputs import devices, Keycode, EventInjector
import time

# Get the window's handle
hwnd = win32gui.FindWindow(None, "Window Title")

# Set the window to the foreground
win32gui.SetForegroundWindow(hwnd)

# Create an event injector object
injector = EventInjector()

# Simulate a key press
injector.inject(Keycode.from_ascii('s'))

# Wait for a short delay
time.sleep(0.1)

# Simulate a key release
injector.inject(Keycode.from_ascii('s'), KeyEvent.KEY_UP)
```

Replace `"Window Title"` with the title of the window you want to send the keystroke to.
Is there anything else I can help you with?

in the terminal it installed correctly: Successfully installed inputs-0.5, but then from inputs import devices, Keycode, EventInjector
ImportError: cannot import name 'Keycode' from 'inputs'

If you're getting an `ImportError: cannot import name 'Keycode' from 'inputs'` error message after trying to import `Keycode` from the `inputs` module, it's possible that you're using an incompatible version of the module.

`inputs` version 0.5 no longer supports using `Keycode`. Instead, the module now uses the `libinput` library to read input events. The `KeyEvent` class can be used to generate keyboard input events while the `MoveEvent` and `ButtonEvent` classes can be used to generate mouse events. 

Here is an example code that sends the 's' key to a window using `libinput`:

```python
import win32gui
from inputs import devices, KeyEvent, EventQueue, InputDevice
import time

# Get the window's handle
hwnd = win32gui.FindWindow(None, "Window Title")

# Set the window to the foreground
win32gui.SetForegroundWindow(hwnd)

# Create an event queue and add a key press and release event for 's'
queue = EventQueue()
queue.put(KeyEvent(devices.Keyboard.KEY_S, 1))
queue.put(KeyEvent(devices.Keyboard.KEY_S, 0))

# Create an input device for the event queue
dev = InputDevice('/dev/input/event22')

# Emit the events
dev.emit(queue)

# Wait for a short delay
```

One alternative is to use the Windows API function `SendInput()` to simulate keyboard input. This function allows you to simulate keystrokes at a low level, bypassing any security or input restrictions that may be in place.

Here is an example code that uses `SendInput()` to send the 's' key to a window:

```python
import win32gui
import win32api
import win32con
import time

# Get the window's handle

# Set the window to the foreground
```

C# 以管理员模式运行的代码
自身启动时用管理员模式运行
还有其它方式吗

还有一种方法可以在自身启动时以管理员身份运行C#程序：使用应用程序清单文件（.manifest文件）。

要使用此方法，请打开Visual Studio中的项目文件，然后添加应用程序清单文件。在应用程序清单文件中，可以添加以下标记来指定应用程序需要以管理员身份运行：

```xml
<requestedExecutionLevel level="requireAdministrator" />
```

将此标记添加到应用程序清单中后，保存并重新编译程序即可。现在，当程序启动时，它将在运行时自动使用管理员权限运行。例如：

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<assembly manifestVersion="1.0" xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1">
    <assemblyIdentity version="1.0.0.0" name="MyApplication.app"/>
    <trustInfo xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v3">
        <security>
            <requestedPrivileges>
                <requestedExecutionLevel level="requireAdministrator" />
            </requestedPrivileges>
        </security>
    </trustInfo>
</assembly>
```

需要注意的是，使用此方法时，程序将始终以管理员身份运行，而不需要提示用户授权。如果您想要程序以非管理员身份启动，请将“level”属性值更改为“asInvoker”即可。
manifest文件怎么添加

要添加应用程序清单文件（.manifest文件），请按照以下步骤：

1. 打开Visual Studio中的项目文件。
2. 在“解决资源管理器”中右键单击项目名称，选择“添加” > “新建项”。
3. 在添加新元素对话框中，选择“清单文件”（Manifest File），输入名称（例如“app.manifest”），然后单击“添加”按钮。
4. Visual Studio将自动为您生成一个基本的清单模板，您可以根据需要进行修改。
5. 在清单文件中的`<requestedExecutionLevel>`元素中，将`level`属性值设置为`"requireAdministrator"`，以表示程序需要使用管理员权限运行。

在您完成了修改后，保存清单文件并重新构建项目。现在，当程序启动时，它将使用管理员权限运行。需要注意的是，一旦将应用程序在具有管理员权限的环境中运行，它将始终以管理员身份运行。
manifest结构是怎么样的，哪里有教程

应用程序清单文件的结构遵循XML标记语言的标准，用于描述Windows应用程序与操作系统之间的关系。该清单文件包含有关应用程序的特定信息，并指定应用程序需要哪些权限和级别。以下是一个示例清单文件：

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<assembly xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1" manifestVersion="1.0">
  <!-- 应用程序标识 -->
  <assemblyIdentity 
    name="ApplicationName" 
    version="1.0.0.0" 
    type="win32" 
    processorArchitecture="x86" />

  <!-- 权限请求 -->
  <trustInfo xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v3">
    <security>
      <requestedPrivileges>
        <requestedExecutionLevel level="requireAdministrator" uiAccess="false" />
      </requestedPrivileges>
    </security>
  </trustInfo>

  <!-- 应用程序依赖项 -->
  <dependency>
    <dependentAssembly>
      <assemblyIdentity 
        name="Microsoft.Windows.Common-Controls" 
        version="6.0.0.0" 
        type="win32" 
        processorArchitecture="x86" 
        publicKeyToken="6595b64144ccf1df" 
        language="*" />
    </dependentAssembly>
  </dependency>
</assembly>
```

清单文件中有三个重要的元素：`<assemblyIdentity>`、`<trustInfo>`和`<dependency>`。其中：

- `<assemblyIdentity>`：用于指定应用程序的名称、版本、类型和体系结构。
- `<trustInfo>`：用于指定应用程序需要哪些特权和级别，如管理员权限（`requireAdministrator`）、用户特权（`requireUserAdministrator`）或低级别用户权限（`asInvoker`）等。
- `<dependency>`：用于指定应用程序的依赖项，如Microsoft Visual C++运行时库、Windows公共控件库等，确保这些依赖项在运行时可用。

如果您需要更深入的说明，可以参考微软的官方文档：[应用程序清单文件 (.manifest)的概述](https://docs.microsoft.com/zh-cn/windows/win32/sbscs/application-manifests)。此文档提供了有关清单文件结构以及如何创建和编辑清单文件的详细信息和示例。
